title: KALLIRHOE
content:
KALLIRHOE (Callirhoe) was a Naiad-nymph of a spring, well or fountain of the city of Troy (north-western
        Anatolia). She was the wife of King Tros, the town's eponymous founder.

GANYMEDES, ILOS, ASSARAKOS, KLEOPATRA (by Tros) (Apollodorus 3.141)

CALLI′RRHOE (Kallirroê). A daughter of Scamander, the wife of Tros, and mother of Ilus and
        Ganymedes. (Apollod. iii. 12. § 2.)

Source: Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology.

Pseudo-Apollodorus, Bibliotheca 3. 141 (trans. Aldrich) (Greek mythographer C2nd
          A.D.) :
        "Tros [king of Troy] married Skamandros' (Scamander's) daughter Kallirrhoe (Callirhoe), had a daughter
        Kleopatra (Cleopatra), and sons Ilos (Ilus), Assarakos (Assaracus), and Ganymedes. Because of his beauty, Zeus
        kidnapped Ganymedes by means of an eagle, and set him as cupbearer in the sky."

Other references not currently quoted here: Dionysius of Halicarnassus 1.62.1.
